intro: Drymonia maculata, commonly known as the spotted bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its bell-shaped, pinkish-white flowers with distinctive red or purple spots. The plant typically grows in moist, sandy soils and thrives in partial to full shade. Its leaves are oval-shaped and have a slightly hairy texture, while its stems are upright and branched. Drymonia maculata is often found in pine flatwoods and wetlands, contributing to the ecological diversity of these habitats.
